DOC.HEAD: Eds: ADDS Bailes; Seperates moved for AMs as a0663 on Greenough, a0627 on Belushi, a0865 on Sisto and as a0868 on Bailes. Greenough also moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: William C. Greenough, developer of the variable-annuity pension and one-time head of the biggest pension fund in the United States, died Wednesday of complications from a heart attack. He was 75. Greenough was president and then chairman of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund from 1957 until his retirement in 1979. He put forward the idea of a variable-annuity stock fund in the early 1950s when he was vice president of the fund. The approach was based on his perception that over the long run a diverse portfolio of common stocks would outperform traditional pensions. Greenough was also a director of the New York Stock Exchange for 10 years beginning in 1972 and in 1979 served on President Carter's Commission on Pension Policy.

Agnes Belushi, mother of actor Jim Belushi and the late actor John Belushi, died Thursday after a bout with cancer. She was 64. She and her husband, Adam, raised their four children in Wheaton, where Belushi owned a restaurant and Mrs. Belushi worked in a pharmacy.

Ernest Sisto, an award-winning photographer who spent 49 years with The New York Times, died at his home Friday at age 85. Sisto was known for his baseball photos, and he was friendly with New York Yankees stars Joe DiMaggio and Phil Rizzuto. He covered many major sporting events, including the World Series and the Kentucky Derby. Sisto was honored for his work by everybody from the Press Photographers Association to a cigar manufacturer. He is survived by his wife, Amelia, and two sons, Daniel and Ernest Jr.

Theodore ``Ted'' L. Richeson, a retired account representative for Westinghouse-KFWB Radio in Los Angeles, died Thursday of heart failure. He was 68. Most of Richeson's career was in broadcasting. His resume included such stations as KREM in Spokane, KCRA in Sacramento and KMPC and KFWB in Los Angeles. He retired from KFWB in 1986. While working in Sacramento as station manager for KCRA radio, Richeson set up KCTC-FM radio, one of the first FM stations in the area. He also served a term as president of the Better Business Bureau. Richeson is survived by his wife of 45 years, Josephine, and three children, Ted, Kelly and Lisa Kalcking.

Thomas Kearns McCarthey, vice president and director of Kearns-Tribune Corp., parent company of The Salt Lake Tribune, died Friday afternoon at age 69. The cause of death was not available. McCarthey was a corporate executive and advertising employee of the Tribune and Newspaper Agency Corp. for more than 40 years. Kearns McCarthey was well-known in newspaper circles, prominent in thoroughbred racing in recent years and active in support of scholarship and athletics at the University of Utah and Judge Memorial Catholic High School. He also was an officer and director of Kearns-Tribune Investments Inc. and Silver King Mining Co. McCarthey is survived by his wife, Jane; three sons, Thomas K. Jr., Philip G. and Shaun McCarthey; two daughters, Sarah Jane and Maureen McCarthey; a sister, Sheila McCarthey Wood; a brother, John P. Brophy; and four granddaughters.

Johnnie Jacob Bailes of Macon, a regular with the Grand Ole Opry in 1943, died Saturday after an extended illness. He was 71. Bailes was a member of the original Bailes Brothers Singing Group formed in 1937. The group appeared regularly on the Grand Ole Opry broadcasts from Nashville, Tenn., in 1943. ``Dust On the Bible,'' one of the Bailes Brothers' songs, is in the Smithsonian Institution. In 1983, the group received a star on the walkway of stars at the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville. Bailes was also one of the founders of the Louisiana Hayride radio show. He moved to Swainsboro in 1956 and worked at WJAT Radio and the Peach State Jamboree. Bailes later became general manager of WJAT, WBRO in Waynesboro and WSNT in Sandersville.
